name: Paris Mash (Rich & Creamy Mashed Potato)
description: Recipe video above. This is mashed potato as served at top tier restaurants. It's soft and almost pourable, intensely buttery and has a more pure potato flavour. Restaurants double pass the potato through a mill then a fine sieve so it's 100% lump free. For this home version, I simply pass the potato through a ricer OR mash it. Nobody notices the imperfections because they're too focussed on the amazing flavour and the creamy yet fluffy texture!
recipeIngredient: 1 kg / 2 lb   Dutch Cream, Desiree, Yukon Gold or Maris Piper potatoes (Note 1)
150 - 200 g / 5 - 7 oz   cold unsalted butter (, cut into 1.5cm / 1/2" cubes (Note 2))

recipeInstructions.text: Place potatoes in a large pot and cover with cold water. Bring to the boil then reduce heat and simmer for 30 to 40 minutes until the potatoes are very soft (depends on size).
recipeInstructions.name: Place potatoes in a large pot and cover with cold water. Bring to the boil then reduce heat and simmer for 30 to 40 minutes until the potatoes are very soft (depends on size).

recipeInstructions.text: Alternatively, peel then chop into 2.5cm / 1" cubes (Note 4), cook 12 to 15 minutes until soft.
recipeInstructions.name: Alternatively, peel then chop into 2.5cm / 1" cubes (Note 4), cook 12 to 15 minutes until soft.

recipeInstructions.text: Drain potatoes and return empty pot to stove.
recipeInstructions.name: Drain potatoes and return empty pot to stove.

recipeInstructions.text: Using tea towels to handle the hot potatoes, peel them using a small knife (skin should slide off pretty easily).
recipeInstructions.name: Using tea towels to handle the hot potatoes, peel them using a small knife (skin should slide off pretty easily).

recipeInstructions.text: Mash the potatoes using one of these methods: Press them through a potato ricer or a food mill / grinder fitted with the finest disc, or mash in the pot using a potato masher (preferably with round holes, yields a similar result to potato ricer).
recipeInstructions.name: Mash the potatoes using one of these methods: Press them through a potato ricer or a food mill / grinder fitted with the finest disc, or mash in the pot using a potato masher (preferably with round holes, yields a similar result to potato ricer).

recipeInstructions.text: Pro step: Then pass the potato through a drum sieve for 100% smooth mashed potato, like you get at restaurants. I do not do this (read in post)
recipeInstructions.name: Pro step: Then pass the potato through a drum sieve for 100% smooth mashed potato, like you get at restaurants. I do not do this (read in post)

recipeInstructions.text: Turn stove on low and stir mashed potato for 1 minute (evaporate excess water).
recipeInstructions.name: Turn stove on low and stir mashed potato for 1 minute (evaporate excess water).

recipeInstructions.text: Add a few cubes of butter and a little splash of milk. Stir until butter melts and is incorporated.
recipeInstructions.name: Add a few cubes of butter and a little splash of milk. Stir until butter melts and is incorporated.

recipeInstructions.text: Repeat until all butter is used up, using milk to adjust the consistency to your desired taste towards the end. It should be soft and creamy, almost pourable.
recipeInstructions.name: Repeat until all butter is used up, using milk to adjust the consistency to your desired taste towards the end. It should be soft and creamy, almost pourable.

recipeInstructions.text: Pour into serving bowl. Use a spoon to create swirls on the surface, top with small dollop of butter and a tiny sprinkle of parsley. Serve immediately!

Loved this recipe! Wondering of it can be made the day before?

Desiree are great, but royal blues are my favourite for this and also baked.
I peel, cut to even sizes and steam them so as to not take up water. This is in a stainless steel uncoated pan because it will keep the heat and not be damaged at the final step.
I prefer a ricer because it is quicker and easier to clean. My wife prefers a food mill because it is quicker and easier to clean!?
I warm the butter so as to not lose heat, the whipping with a fork incorporates it perfectly well. Keep whipping while adding warmed milk a small amount at a time until just prior to saturation and collapse.
Thank you for your knowledgeable and no nonsense lessons.
